facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated May 14, 1958 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1594 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 14, 1958, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1594 of 1956, arising out of the judgment

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and order of Additional Sessions Judge at Kanpur in Criminal Revision No. 13 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order of the Court of Additional Sessions Judge at Kanpur in Criminal Revision No. 13 of 1956. P. Lal, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 24, 1958 by Venkatarama Aiyar, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. November 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR, J.-The facts leading up to this appeal are these On April 26, 1954,

facts.text: Appellant arrested on April 26, 1954 by Sisamau Police for offences under ss. 420, 482, 483, 485 and 486 IPC on allegation of possession of 25 packets of Chand Chhap Biri bearing counterfeit trade marks.

anchor.surface_text: The facts leading up to this appeal are these On April 26, 1954, the appellant was arrested by the Sisamau Police for offences under ss. 420, 482,483, 485 and 486 of the Indian Penal Code on the allegation that he was in possession of 25 packets of Chand Chhap Biri, which were alleged to bear companynterfeit trade marks.

facts.text: On May 26, 1954, Harish Chandra Jain acting on behalf of Messrs. Mohan Lal Hargovind Das filed a complaint charging appellant with possession of counterfeit bidis, wrappers and labels, praying case under mentioned sections be registered and investigated.

anchor.surface_text: On May 26, 1954, one Harish Chandra Jain acting on behalf of Messrs. Mohan Lal Hargovind Das filed a companyplaint charging that the appellant was in possession of companynterfeit bidis, wrappers and labels and praying that a case under the sections above mentioned be registered and investigated.

facts.text: Magistrate passed order to Sisamau Police to investigate and register a case.

anchor.surface_text: On that, the Magistrate passed the following order O. Sisamau. Please investigate and register a case. After investigation, the police submitted their chargesheet
After investigation, the police submitted their chargesheet on September 30, 1954, and summons was ordered to the appellant on July 22, 1955.

facts.text: Summons ordered to appellant on July 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: the police submitted their chargesheet on September 30, 1954, and summons was ordered to the appellant on July 22, 1955. On September 17, 1955, the appellant filed an application

facts.text: On September 17, 1955, appellant filed application before Magistrate raising preliminary objection that proceedings barred by s.15 of Indian Merchandise Marks Act, 1889, as offence discovered on April 26, 1954, and process issued on July 22, 1955 beyond one year.

anchor.surface_text: On September 17, 1955, the appellant filed an application before the Magistrate wherein he raised a preliminary objection that the proceedings were barred by s. 15 of the Indian Merchandise Marks Act, 1889  4 of 1889 , hereinafter referred to as the Act. That section provides No such prosecution as is mentioned in the last foregoing section shall be companymenced after the expiration of three years next after the companymission of the offence, or one year after the first discovery thereof by the prosecutor, whichever expiration first happens. The companytention of the appellant was that the offence was discovered on April 26, 1954, when he was arrested and the goods seized, and that, in companysequence, the issue of process on July 22, 1955, was beyond the period of one year provided under s. 15 of the Act,

and that the proceedings should therefore be quashed as barred by limitation. The Magistrate rejected this companytention, and a Revision Petition preferred against this order to the Additional Sessions Judge, Kanpur,

facts.text: Revision Petition to Additional Sessions Judge, Kanpur in Criminal Revision No. 13 of 1956 rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate rejected this companytention, and a Revision Petition preferred against this order to the Additional Sessions Judge, Kanpur, shared the same fate. The appellant then filed a further Revision Petition to the High Court of Allahabad,

facts.text: Appellant filed Criminal Revision No. 1594 of 1956 in Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: shared the same fate. The appellant then filed a further Revision Petition to the High Court of Allahabad, being Criminal Revision No. 1594 of 1956, and the same was heard along with other similar Revision Petitions

facts.text: Allahabad High Court heard by James and Takru, JJ., judgment dated May 13, 1958 holding prosecution commenced on May 26, 1954, within time under s.15, granted leave to appeal to Supreme Court under Art.134(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: being Criminal Revision No. 1594 of 1956, and the same was heard along with other similar Revision Petitions by a Bench companysisting of James and Takru, JJ. By their judgment dated May 13, 1958, the learned Judges held that the prosecution companymenced when the companyplaint was presented on May 26, 1954, and that as the discovery was on April 26, 1954, the proceedings were within time under s. 15 of the Act. In view of the importance of the question raised, they granted leave to appeal to this Court under Art. 134  1  c  of the Constitution,

facts.text: Supreme Court held that prosecution commences when complaint is preferred, not when process issued, proceedings not barred by s.15.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the decision of the learned Judges of the Court. below that - the, proceedings are number barred by s. 15 of the Act.
The companytention of the appellant was that the offence was discovered on April 26, 1954, when he was arrested and the goods seized,

issues.text: when does a prosecution commence for purposes of s. 15 of the Act, whether on the date when the complaint is preferred, or when the process is issued thereon?

anchor.surface_text: The point for decision is, when does a prosecution commence for purposes of s. 15 of the Act, whether on the date when the complaint is preferred, or when the process is issued thereon?

issues.text: whether the proceedings were barred by s. 15 of the Indian Merchandise Marks Act, 1889

anchor.surface_text: the proceedings were barred by s. 15 of the Indian Merchandise Marks Act, 1889  4 of 1889 , hereinafter referred to as the Act. That section provides No such prosecution as is mentioned in the last foregoing section shall be companymenced after the expiration of three years next after the companymission of the offence, or one year after the first discovery thereof by the prosecutor, whichever expiration first happens.

arguments.claim: The proceedings were barred by s.15 of the Indian Merchandise Marks Act because the issue of process on July 22, 1955 was beyond one year after discovery of the offence on April 26, 1954

anchor.surface_text: the proceedings were barred by s. 15 of the Indian Merchandise Marks Act, 1889  4 of 1889 , hereinafter referred to as the Act. That section provides No such prosecution as is mentioned in the last foregoing section shall be companymenced after the expiration of three years next after the companymission of the offence, or one year after the first discovery thereof by the prosecutor, whichever expiration first happens. The contention of the appellant was that the offence was discovered on April 26, 1954, when he was arrested and the goods seized, and that, in consequence, the issue of process on July 22, 1955, was beyond the period of one year provided under s. 15 of the Act, and that the proceedings should therefore be quashed as barred by limitation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: was arrested, that as numbersanction for his prosecution had been obtained at that time, the proceedings were bad, and that the defect was number cure

arguments.court_reasoning: Prosecution commences on filing of complaint, not issuance of process; proceedings within time

arguments.claim: Prosecution commences only when process is issued, not when complaint is filed

anchor.surface_text: The appellant relies on certain decisions as showing that. the prosecution must be held to commence only when process is issued and not when complaint is filed. In Sheik Meeran Sahib v. Ratnavelu Mudali 1 , De Rozario v. Gulab Chand Anundjee 2 and Golap Jan v. Bholanath Khettry 3 cited by the appellant, the question was whether an action for damages for malicious prosecution would lie when the complaint was dismissed without notice to the plaintiff.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mber would be wholly foreign to it. Indeed, in an action for damages for malicious prosecution, when it is held that there was prosecution, that compa

arguments.court_reasoning: Those cases concern malicious prosecution actions where damage requires process issuance; irrelevant to when prosecution commences for limitation under the Act

arguments.claim: Prosecution commences only when process is issued, as per R.R. Chari v. State of UP

anchor.surface_text: The decision in R. R. Chari v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1 was relied on by the appellant as showing that until process was issued, there was no prosecution. There, the appellant was proceeded against under the provisions. of the Prevention of Corruption Act No. 2 of 1947.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e prosecution obtained the necessary sanction under the Act. The companytention of the appellant was that the prosecution must be held to have been in

arguments.court_reasoning: R.R. Chari applies to police investigation under special Act; here private complaint under CrPC s.190(1)(a), cognizance on receipt of complaint

arguments.claim: Under general law, prosecution at instance of private prosecutor commences when complaint is preferred

anchor.surface_text: The point for decision is, when does a prosecution commence for purposes of s. 15 of the Act, whether on the date when the complaint is preferred, or when the process is issued thereon? The word prosecution is not defined in the Act, nor are there any provisions therein bearing on this question. Now, under the law and apart from statutory prescriptions, a prosecution commences, where it is at the instance of a private prosecutor, when the complaint is preferred. The position is thus stated in Halsburys Laws of England, Vol. X, 3rd Edn., p. 340, para. 630 Criminal prosecutions, except where there are statutory provisions to the contrary, may be commenced at any time after the commission of the offence.

arguments.claim: Prosecution under s.15 commences on presentation of complaint; settled law unless statute provides otherwise

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore settled law that unless there is something to the contrary in the statute, when a private complaint is presented it is the date of presentation thereof that marks the commencement of the prosecution.

arguments.claim: Nature of proceedings under the Act is private prosecution by trader to protect trade mark rights promptly; limitation ensures prosecutor's diligence, not court's process speed

anchor.surface_text: Now, what is the nature of the prosecution under s. 15 of the Act ? It is relevant in this connection to refer to ss. 13 and 14... The object of the above provisions is to protect the rights of persons who manufacture and sell goods with distinct trade marks against invasion by other persons passing off their goods fraudulently and with counterfeit trade marks as those of the manufacturers... It will defeat the object of the enactment and deprive traders of the protection which the law intended to give them, if we were to hold that unless process is issued on their complaint within one year of the discovery of the offence, it should be thrown out.

arguments.claim: As per Ruppell v. Ponnuswami, complaint presentation within one year satisfies s.15

anchor.surface_text: in Ruppell v. Ponnuswami Tewan 1 , the question rose whether a prosecution launched by the complainant in 1898 in respect of goods sold and marked with what was alleged to be, a counterfeit trade mark in 1893 was in time. In deciding that it was barred under s. 15 of the Act... That means that if the complaint is presented within one year of such discovery, the requirements of s. 15 are satisfied.

arguments.claim: Cases cited by appellant (Sheik Meeran etc.) are distinguishable as they concern malicious prosecution damages requiring actual prosecution stage with damage

anchor.surface_text: These decisions have no bearing on the present question. In suits for damages for malicious prosecution, one of the points to be decided is, whether the plaintiff was, in fact, prosecuted... On the other hand, the point for decision in a prosecution under the Act is, not whether there was a prosecution but when it was instituted...

arguments.claim: R.R. Chari distinguishable: applies to police arrest under Prevention of Corruption Act, not private complaint under CrPC s.190(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: But here, we are dealing with a private complaint, and as pointed out at p. 315 of the Report, s. 190 1 a of the Criminal Procedure Code would apply to such cases, and the Magistrate must be held to have taken cognizance when the complaint was received. This decision, in our opinion, does not assist the appellant nor does the decision in Gopal Marwari v. King-Emperor 2 .

arguments.claim: Prosecution commenced when complaint presented on May 26, 1954, within one year of discovery on April 26, 1954

anchor.surface_text: By their judgment dated May 13, 1958, the learned Judges held that the prosecution commenced when the complaint was presented on May 26, 1954, and that as the discovery was on April 26, 1954, the proceedings were within time under s. 15 of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: was arrested, that as numbersanction for his prosecution had been obtained at that time, the proceedings were bad, and that the defect was number cure

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees with this view

arguments.claim: Proceedings not barred by s.15 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the decision of the learned Judges of the Court. below that - the, proceedings are not barred by s. 15 of the Act.

holdings.text: A prosecution at the instance of a private prosecutor commences when the complaint is preferred.

anchor.surface_text: Now, under the law and apart from statutory prescriptions, a prosecution commences, where it is at the instance of a private prosecutor, when the complaint is preferred. The position is thus stated in Halsburys Laws of England, Vol. X, 3rd Edn., p. 340, para. 630 Criminal prosecutions, except where there are statutory provisions to the contrary, may be commenced at any time after the commission of the offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General common law rule as stated in Halsbury's Laws of England: prosecution commences when information laid before justice in private complaints, absent statutory variation.

holdings.text: It is settled law that unless there is something to the contrary in the statute, the date of presentation of a private complaint marks the commencement of the prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore settled law that unless there is something to the contrary in the statute, when a private complaint is presented it is the date of presentation thereof that marks the commencement of the prosecution. Now, what is the nature of the prosecution under s. 15 of the Act ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: No definition of 'prosecution' or relevant provision in the Act; general rule applies.

holdings.text: If the complaint is presented within one year of discovery of the offence by the prosecutor, the requirements of s.15 are satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: That means that if the complaint is presented within one year of such discovery, the requirements of s. 15 are satisfied. The period of limitation, it should be remembered, is intended to operate against the complainant and to ensure diligence on his part in prosecuting his rights, and not against the Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpreting s.15 per Ruppell v. Ponnuswami; limitation targets prosecutor's diligence, not court delays; confirmed by Act's purpose to provide speedy remedy for traders.

holdings.text: The proceedings are not barred by s.15 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the decision of the learned Judges of the Court. below that - the, proceedings are not barred by s. 15 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Complaint preferred on May 26, 1954, within one year of discovery on April 26, 1954; applies rule that commencement is on filing; agrees with High Court.

holdings.text: Cases like Sheik Meeran Sahib v. Ratnavelu Mudali, De Rozario v. Gulab Chand Anundjee, and Golap Jan v. Bholanath Khettry do not govern when a prosecution commences for limitation purposes under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: These decisions have no bearing on the present question. In suits for damages for malicious prosecution, one of the points to be decided is, whether the plaintiff was, in fact, prosecuted... On the other hand, the point for decision in a prosecution under the Act is, not whether there was a prosecution but when it was instituted...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Those cases address whether prosecution occurred for malicious prosecution damages (requiring process); here, issue is timing of institution for limitation.

holdings.text: R.R. Chari v. State of Uttar Pradesh does not apply to private complaints under the Merchandise Marks Act.

anchor.surface_text: But here, we are dealing with a private complaint, and as pointed out at p. 315 of the Report, s. 190 1 a of the Criminal Procedure Code would apply to such cases, and the Magistrate must be held to have taken cognizance when the complaint was received. This decision, in our opinion, does not assist the appellant nor does the decision in Gopal Marwari v. King-Emperor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: R.R. Chari concerns police arrest under special Prevention of Corruption Act; here, private complaint triggers CrPC s.190(1)(a) cognizance on receipt.

precedents.citation: Ruppell v. Ponnuswami Tewan  1  1899  I.L.R. 22 Mad. 488

anchor.surface_text: in Ruppell v. Ponnuswami Tewan  1 , the question rose whether a prosecution launched by the companyplainant in 1898 in respect of goods sold and marked with what was alleged to be, a companynterfeit trade mark in 1893 was in time. In deciding that it was a barred under s. 15 of the Act, the Court observed as follows Section 15 of the Merchandise Mark, Act IV of 1889, enacts that numberprosecution such as the present shall be companymenced after the expiration of one year after the first discovery of the offence by the prosecutor.

precedents.cited_proposition: Prosecution under s.15 Merchandise Marks Act commences on presentation of complaint within one year of discovery by prosecutor; limitation ensures diligence of complainant, not delay by court
precedents.cited_holding: If complaint presented within one year of discovery, s.15 requirements satisfied; limitation operates against complainant

precedents.citation: Sheik Meeran Sahib v. Ratnavelu Mudali  1  1912  I.L.R. 37 Mad. 181

anchor.surface_text: In Sheik Meeran Sahib v. Ratnavelu Mudali  1 , De Rozario v. Gulab Chand Anundjee  2  and Golap Jan v. Bholanath Khettry  3  cited by the appellant, the question was whether an action for damages for malicious prosecution would lie when the companyplaint was dismissed without numberice to the plaintiff. It was held that the plaintiff companyld number be held to have been prosecuted unless process was issued to him and that where the companyplaint was dismissed without such process being issued, there was numberprosecution and numberaction for damages in respect of such prosecution would lie.

precedents.case_name: Sheik Meeran Sahib v. Ratnavelu Mudali
precedents.cited_proposition: No prosecution unless process issued to accused; complaint dismissed without process does not constitute prosecution for malicious prosecution action
precedents.cited_holding: Plaintiff could not be held prosecuted unless process issued

precedents.citation: De Rozario v. Gulab Chand Anundjee  2  1910  I.L.R. 37 Cal. 358

anchor.surface_text: In Sheik Meeran Sahib v. Ratnavelu Mudali  1 , De Rozario v. Gulab Chand Anundjee  2  and Golap Jan v. Bholanath Khettry  3  cited by the appellant, the question was whether an action for damages for malicious prosecution would lie when the companyplaint was dismissed without numberice to the plaintiff. It was held that the plaintiff companyld number be held to have been prosecuted unless process was issued to him and that where the companyplaint was dismissed without such process being issued, there was numberprosecution and numberaction for damages in respect of such prosecution would lie.

precedents.case_name: De Rozario v. Gulab Chand Anundjee
precedents.cited_proposition: No prosecution unless process issued to accused; complaint dismissed without process does not constitute prosecution for malicious prosecution action
precedents.cited_holding: No action for damages where complaint dismissed without process

precedents.citation: Golap Jan v. Bholanath Khettry  3  1911  I.L.R. 38 Cal. 890

anchor.surface_text: In Sheik Meeran Sahib v. Ratnavelu Mudali  1 , De Rozario v. Gulab Chand Anundjee  2  and Golap Jan v. Bholanath Khettry  3  cited by the appellant, the question was whether an action for damages for malicious prosecution would lie when the companyplaint was dismissed without numberice to the plaintiff. It was held that the plaintiff companyld number be held to have been prosecuted unless process was issued to him

precedents.cited_proposition: No prosecution unless process issued to accused; complaint dismissed without process does not constitute prosecution for malicious prosecution action
precedents.cited_holding: Prosecution commences when complaint filed in malicious prosecution context

precedents.citation: Mohamed Amin v. Jogendra Kumar Bannerjee  4  1947 A.C. 322, 331

anchor.surface_text: It may be that these decisions may have to be reconsidered in the light of the recent decision of the Privy Council in Mohamed Amin v. Jogendra Kumar Bannerjee  4 , wherein it was observed The test is number whether the criminal proceedings have reached a stage at which they may be described as a prosecution the test is whether such proceedings have reached a stage at which damage to the plaintiff results. Vide also Ramaswami Iyer on The Law of Torts, 4th Edn., p. 318.

precedents.case_name: Mohamed Amin v. Jogendra Kumar Bannerjee
precedents.cited_proposition: Test for prosecution in malicious prosecution is whether proceedings reached stage causing damage to plaintiff, not mere filing
precedents.cited_holding: Criminal proceedings become prosecution when damage results to plaintiff

precedents.citation: R. R. Chari v. The State of Uttar Pradesh  1  1951 S.C.R. 312

anchor.surface_text: The decision in R. R. Chari v. The State of Uttar Pradesh  1  was relied on by the appellant as showing that until process was issued, there was numberprosecution. There, the appellant was proceeded against under the provisions. of the Prevention of Corruption Act No. 2 of 1947. The Deputy Magistrate, Kanpur, issued a warrant for his arrest on October 22, 1947. Thereafter, on December 6, 1948, the prosecution obtained the necessary sanction under the Act.

precedents.case_name: R. R. Chari v. The State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Under Prevention of Corruption Act, police arrest pending investigation does not commence prosecution; cognizance on receipt of complaint under CrPC s.190(1)(a)
precedents.cited_holding: No prosecution on date of arrest; Magistrate takes cognizance when complaint received

precedents.citation: Gopal Marwari v. King-Emperor  2  1943  I.L.R. 22 Pat- 433

anchor.surface_text: This decision, in our opinion, does number assist the appellant number does the decision in Gopal Marwari v. King-Emperor  2 . There, companysidering ss. 200 and 202 of the Criminal Procedure Code, the learned Judges observed that there was a distinction between initiation of proceedings before the Magistrate and his taking companynizance of the same. It is Sufficient to say that that is number the question which we have got to -decide here,

precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between initiation of proceedings before Magistrate and taking cognizance under CrPC ss.200 and 202

anchor.surface_text: That means that if the complaint is presented within one year of such discovery, the requirements of s. 15 are satisfied. The period of limitation, it should be remembered, is intended to operate against the complainant and to ensure diligence on his part in prosecuting his rights, and not against the Court.
We agree with the decision of the learned Judges of the Court. below that - the, proceedings are number barred by s. 15 of the Act.
We agree with the decision of the learned Judges of the Court. below that - the, proceedings are not barred by s. 15 of the Act.
We agree with the decision of the learned Judges of the Court. below that - the, proceedings are number barred by s. 15 of the Act.
We agree with the decision of the learned Judges of the Court. below that - the, proceedings are number barred by s. 15 of the Act.
We agree with the decision of the learned Judges of the Court. below that - the, proceedings are number barred by s. 15 of the Act.

edges.explanation: Resolving when prosecution commences under s.15 (i1) requires interpreting c6 (s.15)
h1 directly holds that prosecution commences when complaint is preferred, addressing the core question in i1
h2 holds that presentation of private complaint marks commencement unless statute otherwise, addressing i1
Whether barred by s.15 (i2) requires application of c6
h4 holds proceedings not barred by s.15, directly addressing i2
Deciding if barred by s.15 (i2) requires determining commencement timing (i1)
a7 explicitly relies on Ruppell v. Ponnuswami (p1)
p1 holds prosecution under s.15 commences on complaint presentation, supporting c6
p1 directly supports h3 that complaint within year satisfies s.15
